study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ketogenic (KD) and high-fat/low-carbohydrate (HF/LC) diets on gut microbiome alterations and tumor growth in a mouse model of ovarian cancer.
results_summary: KD and HF/LC diets significantly accelerated tumor growth compared to a low-fat/high-carbohydrate (LF/HC) diet, correlating with reduced gut microbiome diversity. Metagenomic analyses identified distinct microbial taxa and functional pathway alterations across diet groups.
population_specificity: Female C57BL/6J mice injected with KPCA cells (syngeneic model of high-grade serous ovarian cancer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how different dietary fat sources affect the gut microbiota composition and predicted function in broiler chickens, comparing them to poultry fat.
results_summary: The study found that treatment time had a stronger effect on microbiota shifts than dietary treatment alone, but diet combined with time was significant. Fish- and flaxseed-based diets showed diet-specific effects on butyrate-producing species, and flaxseed-based diets indicated potential host health benefits through predicted functional pathways.
population_specificity: Broiler chickens
study_duration: Evaluated at day 41 and day 55 of age

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how different types of dietary fats influence the expression of neurotransmitter transporters (DAT and 5-HTT) and oxidative stress in broiler chickens.
results_summary: Flaxseed oil (FLAX) significantly increased DAT and 5-HTT expression without causing oxidative stress, while coconut oil (COCO), canola oil (CANO), and the control (CON) showed higher oxidative stress levels. Dietary fat types did not negatively affect growth performance.
population_specificity: Male broiler chicks (Ross 708)
effective_dosage: 3% supplementation of various fats (poultry fat, olive oil, fish oil, canola oil, lard, coconut oil, flaxseed oil)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different dietary fat concentrations (from rapeseed and palm kernel) on methane reduction, feed intake, digestibility, and milk production in dairy cows.
results_summary: Increased dietary fat from rapeseed and palm kernel reduced methane yield, with palm kernel showing a stronger effect but also reducing milk production. Rapeseed supplementation up to 5.7% of DM increased milk yield, while higher concentrations did not further improve productivity.
population_specificity: Forty-eight dairy cows (half primiparous, half multiparous).
effective_dosage: Total crude fat concentrations ranged from 3% to 7% of DM, with low, medium, and high concentrations for rapeseed and low and medium for palm kernel.
study_duration: Six periods of 21 days each (total 126 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how replacing saturated fats with unsaturated fats affects lipid metabolite concentrations and its association with cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes risk.
results_summary: The study found that improved dietary fat quality, reflected by a multilipid score (MLS), was associated with a significant reduction in cardiovascular disease (-32%) and type 2 diabetes (-26%). Beneficial changes in a simplified score (rMLS) over 10 years were linked to lower diabetes risk, particularly in individuals with initially unfavorable lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: EPIC-Potsdam cohort, Nurses' Health Study participants, and PREDIMED trial participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how saturated fatty acids activate the NAD+ salvage pathway in hypothalamic astrocytes and its role in hypothalamic inflammation and obesity development.
results_summary: The study found that saturated fatty acids activate the NAD+ salvage pathway in hypothalamic astrocytes, leading to inflammation and obesity in male mice. Inhibition of this pathway reduced inflammation and obesity, with CD38 identified as a downstream mediator.
population_specificity: Male mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of high dietary fat levels in low or high energy density diets on gut function, amino acid utilization, oxidative stress, and microbial metabolites in weaned piglets.
results_summary: A high energy density/high-fat diet increased feed intake, body weight gain, and gut absorptive function but also induced diarrhea and elevated oxidative stress markers. The low energy density/high-fat diet showed mixed effects on gut morphology and amino acid concentrations.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets (16 healthy weaners, 9.60 ± 0.13 kg).
effective_dosage: Not specified (two dietary treatments: low energy density/high-fat and high energy density/high-fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of modified dietary fat intake in the treatment of gallstone disease in people of any age.
results_summary: The study found scant evidence about the effects of modifying dietary fat on gallstone disease, with no significant effect of a low-cholesterol diet on gallstone dissolution reported. No serious adverse events were noted, but the trial was assessed as high risk of bias and lacked data on primary outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with gallstones diagnosed via ultrasonography or conclusive imaging methods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of dietary counseling and other nutritional interventions, including intradialytic parenteral nutrition (IDPN), for managing protein-energy wasting (PEW) in chronic kidney disease patients.
results_summary: Dietary counseling and food supplements are standard methods for increasing nutritional intake in chronic kidney disease patients with PEW, but the abstract does not provide specific results for dietary counseling alone. IDPN, another intervention discussed, showed a good safety profile and potential improvement in protein-energy status, though study limitations were noted.
population_specificity: Patients with stages 4 and 5 chronic kidney disease, particularly maintenance dialysis patients with or at risk of protein-energy wasting (PEW).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of dietary fat in tumor microenvironment metabolism and its implications for cancer progression and therapeutic strategies.
results_summary: The study highlights that excessive lipid accumulation promotes cancer initiation and progression, while diets like calorie restriction may delay cancer. It emphasizes the metabolic crosstalk between cancer cells and the tumor microenvironment, including immune and stromal components.
population_specificity: Cancer cells and tumor microenvironment components (immune and stromal cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how depression affects fat absorption and whether Si-Ni-San (SNS) could reverse weight loss and improve fat absorption in depressed mice.
results_summary: The study found that depressed mice had impaired fat absorption, leading to weight loss and reduced lipid levels, which SNS reversed by upregulating key proteins in the fat absorption pathway. SNS and its active components (Sinensetin and Nobiletin) also regulated lipid absorption in LPS-stimulated cells, partly via the NR1D1/BMAL1/DGAT2 axis.
population_specificity: Depressed mice and LPS-stimulated mouse MODE-K and human Caco-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether feeding dietary fish fat during puppyhood was associated with a reduced risk of epilepsy in adult dogs.
results_summary: Feeding fish fat at least once a week during puppyhood was inversely associated with epilepsy in adulthood, showing a protective effect in unadjusted and partially adjusted analyses, though significance was lost when fully adjusted for other feeding factors. The findings align with existing knowledge on omega-3 fatty acids and ketogenic diets in epilepsy management.
population_specificity: Dogs (specifically puppies, later assessed for epilepsy in adulthood)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of varying dietary fat levels in concentrate mixes on growth performance, rumen characteristics, digestibility, blood metabolites, and methane emissions in growing Hanwoo steers.
results_summary: Increasing dietary fat levels reduced concentrate mix dry matter intake and methane emissions linearly, while growth rate and digestibility remained unaffected. Blood serum cholesterol increased significantly with higher fat levels, and ruminal propionate increased while butyrate and acetate-to-propionate ratio decreased.
population_specificity: Growing Hanwoo steers (12 months old, 386 ± 24.6 kg body weight).
effective_dosage: 48, 74, and 99 g of ether extract per kg dry matter in concentrate mixes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a lysophosphatidylcholine (LPC)-rich structured lipid powder increased fat absorption of coingested food in individuals with malabsorption.
results_summary: The study found that the LPC product increased plasma palmitic acid by 15% in total subjects and 23% in a subgroup with severe malabsorption, while total fatty acids increased by 11% and 20%, respectively, suggesting improved dietary fat absorption.
population_specificity: Children with cystic fibrosis and pancreatic insufficiency (n = 84).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how dietary fats influence gut microbiota and satiation signaling pathways, and how these mechanisms contribute to obesity.
results_summary: The study found that dietary fats induce taxonomic shifts in gut microbiota, which in turn affect satiation signals (gut hormones and neuropeptides) and promote hyperphagia, contributing to obesity. Dietary interventions and microbiota-optimizing therapies (prebiotics, probiotics, synbiotics, surgery) may restore beneficial gut microbiota and enhance satiety signals to reduce obesity.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of mechanisms, not a clinical trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a fat intake biomarker, adjust self-reported fat intake for measurement error, and study associations of biomarker-calibrated fat intake with chronic disease risk in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Higher fat density was associated with increased risks of breast cancer, coronary heart disease, and diabetes, aligning with prior trial findings. After controlling for additional dietary variables like fiber, fat density remained associated with breast cancer but not CHD.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 50-79 enrolled at 40 US clinical centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between changes in dietary fat intake (SFA vs. MUFA) and changes in fatty acid levels in serum cholesterol esters, as well as the impact of fish oil supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that serum cholesterol ester fatty acid composition reflected dietary intake, with SFA intake linked to specific saturated fatty acids (C14:0, C15:0) and MUFA intake associated with oleic acid (C18:1 n-9). Fish oil supplementation significantly increased EPA (C20:5 n-3) and DHA (C22:6 n-3) levels, and Δ-9 desaturase activity was more reduced after the MUFA diet compared to the SFA diet.
population_specificity: 162 healthy individuals from a multinational population.
effective_dosage: Not specified (diets contained a high proportion of SFA or MUFA; fish oil or placebo supplements were used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effects of a high-fat diet and carbonated soda consumption on oxidative stress and inflammation in Wistar rats.
results_summary: The study found that a high-fat diet combined with soda increased anthropometric variables and lipid peroxidation while decreasing antioxidant levels, indicating heightened oxidative stress and inflammation.
population_specificity: Male and female Wistar rats (n=32).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between dietary fat quality (h/H ratio) and CVD risk factors in hemodialysis patients and explore the impact of nutritional education interventions on improving these factors.
results_summary: The study found that the h/H ratio was negatively correlated with BMI and positively correlated with HDL-C. Nutritional education for both patients and nurses (CPN group) significantly improved the h/H ratio, increased HDL-C, and reduced serum total cholesterol compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of saturated and unsaturated high-fat diets on liver regeneration following partial hepatectomy in mice.
results_summary: Mice fed high-fat diets (saturated or unsaturated) exhibited higher NAFLD scores, increased inflammation, and impaired liver regeneration compared to those on a low-fat diet. The saturated fat diet showed worse outcomes in terms of inflammation and regeneration than the unsaturated fat diet.
population_specificity: Mice with induced hepatic steatosis undergoing partial hepatectomy.
effective_dosage: Low-fat control diet (13% fat), lard-based unsaturated high-fat diet (60% fat), milk-based saturated high-fat diet (60% fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors that protect or predispose gastrointestinal organs to high-fat diet (HFD)-induced neoplasia, focusing on leptin receptor (LepR) signaling and its role in stomach and colorectal tissues.
results_summary: The study found that HFD activates leptin signaling, leading to neoplasia in the stomach more than in the colorectum, with ectopic TFF3 expression and activation of EGFR, STAT3, and Akt pathways. LepR deletion suppressed these effects in the stomach but not significantly in the colorectum, suggesting a novel role for LepR-mediated signaling in transactivating EGFR via the PI3K-Akt pathway.
population_specificity: Mice with gastrointestinal epithelium-specific LepR deletion and COS-7 cells transfected with LepR and EGFR plasmid DNA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between dietary fat intake (including saturated, monounsaturated, and polyunsaturated fats) and outcomes like all-cause mortality and cancer progression in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer.
results_summary: Higher vegetable fat intake was associated with lower risks of all-cause mortality and cancer progression or death, while no other types of fat showed significant associations. The study found statistically significant hazard ratios favoring moderate or higher vegetable fat consumption.
population_specificity: 1149 patients with advanced or metastatic colorectal cancer (median age 59, 41% female, 86% White).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different dietary fatty acid compositions affect bile acid metabolism and the progression of NAFLD in a pig model.
results_summary: Coconut oil (COC) increased primary and secondary bile acids in liver, plasma, and colon compared to lard (LAR) and olive oil (OLI). Both COC and OLI worsened liver disease markers, including necrosis and liver enzymes, but these changes were not linked to bile acid pool alterations.
population_specificity: Juvenile Iberian pigs (30 animals, 20 days old).
effective_dosage: Hypercaloric diets enriched with lard, olive oil, or coconut oil (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between dietary fat intake and hyperuricemia in males with and without reduced kidney function.
results_summary: The study found that higher intake of saturated, monounsaturated, and polyunsaturated fatty acids was associated with lower uric acid levels, particularly in men with reduced kidney function, suggesting dietary fat may help prevent or treat hyperuricemia in this population.
population_specificity: 361 males (mean age 60.7 years) from Shika Town, Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how modulation of bile acid metabolism by dietary fat content, gallbladder removal, and bile acid sequestrant treatment affects energy, glucose, and lipid metabolism via changes in the gut microbiota.
results_summary: High-fat diets (HFD) increased body weight gain and insulin resistance compared to low-fat diets (LFD), with gallbladder removal exacerbating these effects. Bile acid sequestrant (BAS) treatment improved serum lipid profiles but increased hepatic inflammation markers. Gut microbiota diversity and composition were significantly altered by dietary fat, gallbladder removal, and BAS treatment.
population_specificity: Mice (animal study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a dietary exchange model replacing saturated fatty acids (SFAs) with unsaturated fatty acids (UFAs) using commercially available foods.
results_summary: Participants successfully exchanged 10.2%TE SFAs for 9.7%TE UFAs, achieving target intakes without altering overall dietary patterns. Plasma phospholipid fatty acid profiles confirmed compliance with the intervention.
population_specificity: Healthy men (n=109, mean age 48 years).
effective_dosage: High-SFA diet (18%TE SFAs, 16%TE UFAs) and low-SFA diet (10%TE SFAs, 24%TE UFAs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of altering the ratio of palmitic, stearic, and oleic acids in dietary fat on nutritional metabolism, growth performance, and meat quality in finishing Angus bulls.
results_summary: Both fat-supplemented diets increased saturated and monounsaturated fatty acids in muscle, improving the unsaturated-to-saturated fatty acid ratio. The MIX diet enhanced digestibility of dry matter, crude protein, and ether extract, while the SFA diet improved daily weight gain and intramuscular fat content by upregulating lipid uptake genes.
population_specificity: Finishing Angus bulls

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOS)-mediated nitric oxide generation in GLP-2-mediated dietary fat absorption and chylomicron production.
results_summary: The study found that GLP-2 significantly increased postprandial lipid accumulation and apolipoprotein B48 levels in wild-type mice, effects abolished in nNOS-/- mice. Inhibition of nNOS or protein kinase G (PKG) also blocked GLP-2's effects, indicating an nNOS-PKG pathway is crucial for GLP-2-mediated fat absorption.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice, nNOS-/- mice, and Syrian golden hamsters.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how a high-fat/low-fiber "Western-type" diet affects mortality and gut microbiome disruption in a murine model of antibiotic-induced Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI).
results_summary: Mice fed a high-fat/low-fiber diet had dramatically increased mortality, higher levels of pro-C. difficile bile acids, and greater gut microbiome disruption compared to low-fat/low-fiber and standard chow diets. The high-fat diet was also associated with elevated toxin TcdA levels prior to mortality.
population_specificity: Laboratory mice in an antibiotic-induced CDI model.
effective_dosage: Not specified (diet composition described as "high-fat/low-fiber" and "low-fat/low-fiber").

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify plasma lipids associated with cardiometabolic disease risk and test if dietary fat modification (replacing saturated fats with unsaturated fats) could beneficially alter these risk-associated lipids.
results_summary: The study identified 69 lipids associated with cardiometabolic diseases, with 19 of these risk-associated lipids being beneficially altered by diets rich in unsaturated fats compared to saturated fats, suggesting potential for primary disease prevention.
population_specificity: 27,548 participants aged 35-65 from the general population around Potsdam, Germany, with subsets for cardiovascular disease (n=551) and type 2 diabetes (n=775) cases.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary intervention focused on fat composition rather than fixed dosage).
study_duration: 16 weeks (for the DIVAS randomized controlled trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of maternal high-fat diet (HFD) and metformin exposure during lactation on milk composition, mammary gland function, and offspring metabolic health.
results_summary: Maternal HFD increased adipose tissue weight, altered milk lipid composition (higher omega-6, lower omega-3 fatty acids), and led to heavier offspring with more body fat. Metformin reduced maternal blood glucose and milk amino acids, resulting in smaller offspring but did not rescue the effects of HFD.
population_specificity: Lactating dams and their offspring (studied on postnatal day 16).
interactions: Metformin altered some effects of HFD but did not fully counteract them.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of substituting dietary barley grain with different sources and levels of fat on performance and meat quality in Holstein young bulls.
results_summary: The study found that replacing dietary starch with fat supplements did not negatively affect calves' performance or digestibility of neutral detergent fibre, and acid detergent fibre digestibility improved with both fat sources. Dry matter intake, average daily gain, feed conversion ratio, and carcass traits remained unaffected by fat supplementation.
population_specificity: Holstein male calves (initial body weight 274 ± 32 kg).
effective_dosage: Low and high levels of saturated (Energizer® RP10) and unsaturated (Persiafat) fat supplements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the interaction between dietary fat intake and genetic factors on metabolic disease-related traits in young Brazilian adults.
results_summary: The study found significant interactions between a metabolic-genetic risk score and total fat intake on fasting insulin levels, insulin-glucose ratio, and HOMA-B, with higher fat intake and genetic risk associated with worse metabolic outcomes.
population_specificity: 200 healthy Brazilian young adults
effective_dosage: High-fat intake category (37.98 ± 3.39% of total energy intake)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if replacing dietary fat with polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) could reduce LPS-induced hepatic inflammation in rats fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: Partial replacement of dietary fat with PUFAs (perilla oil and corn oil) lowered serum glucose and insulin levels, reduced hepatic triglyceride accumulation, and attenuated inflammation and ER stress markers in the liver of LPS-injected rats.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of dietary fat composition in modulating gastrointestinal disorders (GID) in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) through its effects on the gut microbiome.
results_summary: The study suggests that high-fat diets, particularly those rich in saturated fatty acids, may negatively impact gut microbiome diversity and increase GID risk in children with ASD, while omega-3 fatty acids may have beneficial anti-inflammatory effects. However, the data presented were inconsistent, highlighting the need for further experimental studies.
population_specificity: Children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) experiencing gastrointestinal disorders (GID).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether reducing dietary fat content could prevent acute pancreatitis recurrence in idiopathic cases.
results_summary: The study is designed to compare the effects of a reduced-fat diet (15% fat) versus a standard healthy diet (30% fat) on pancreatitis recurrence, mortality, serum lipids, and weight loss, but results are not yet available as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Patients with at least 2 episodes of acute pancreatitis in the preceding 2 years, with the last episode being idiopathic.
effective_dosage: Reduced-fat diet (15% fat, 65% carbohydrate, 20% protein) vs. standard healthy diet (30% fat, 50% carbohydrate, 20% protein).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between dietary fat intake and breast cancer development, focusing on different types and sources of fatty acids.
results_summary: The study found that higher intake of total fat, polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs), animal fat, saturated fatty acids (SFAs), and monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFAs) was associated with increased breast cancer risk, particularly in postmenopausal women. No association was observed in premenopausal women.
population_specificity: 473 women with pathologically confirmed breast cancer and 501 healthy age- and residency-matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 25% caloric restriction of a high-fat diet (HFD) on weight loss, metabolic parameters, and hypothalamic neuropeptide expression in obese rats.
results_summary: A 25% restriction of HFD led to a 36% weight loss, normalized adiposity index and food efficiency ratio, and improved hypothalamic neuropeptide expression (NPY, AgRP, POMC) and hormone levels (ghrelin, leptin). However, it did not improve glucose homeostasis despite reducing hyperinsulinemia.
population_specificity: Ten-week-old male Wistar rats (n = 40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how high-fat diets (HFD) affect dopamine neurotransmission in the nucleus accumbens (NAc) and food intake, and how stress and inflammation influence this process.
results_summary: The study found that HFD reduces dopamine release and reuptake, potentially disrupting satiety circuits and promoting weight gain by altering responses to food cues and stress. Saturated fat also promotes neuronal resistance to anorectic hormones and activates immune cells that release proinflammatory cytokines, further impairing dopamine signaling.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing evidence)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of insulin strategies for managing glycaemia after meals containing fat and/or fat and protein in individuals with type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that additional insulin (24%-75% of the insulin-to-carbohydrate ratio) improved glycaemic control for fat and fat-protein meals. Optimal insulin delivery involved a combination bolus with at least 60% upfront dose administered 15 minutes before the meal.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 1 diabetes
effective_dosage: Additional 30%-51% insulin-to-carbohydrate ratio (ICR) for meals with 32-50g fat or 7-35g fat plus 12-27g protein

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which a high-fat diet combined with alcohol consumption contributes to steatohepatitis and liver injury.
results_summary: The study found that combining a high-fat diet with alcohol significantly worsened liver injury and steatohepatitis, marked by increased oxidative stress, endoplasmic reticulum stress, and activation of CHOP and caspase-12, but not mitochondria-mediated apoptosis.
population_specificity: Rat model (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: 20% fat diet + 10% alcohol (half-dose) and 40% fat diet + 20% alcohol (double-dose).
interactions: Alcohol (synergistic negative effect with high-fat diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between maternal dietary fat intake during pregnancy and newborn adiposity.
results_summary: Maternal dietary fat intake, particularly during the second trimester, was positively correlated with infant percent body fat, suggesting a key period for fetal adipose tissue metabolic programming.
population_specificity: 79 singleton pregnancies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between dietary fat intake (specifically replacing saturated fats with polyunsaturated fats or carbohydrates) and cardiovascular disease risk in adults with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Replacing saturated fats with polyunsaturated fats or carbohydrates was associated with reduced cardiovascular disease occurrence, though the quality of evidence was low to very-low. Higher polyunsaturated-to-saturated fat intake also correlated with reduced cardiovascular disease risk.
population_specificity: Adults with type 2 diabetes (22,591 participants in prospective studies, 14 in a trial).
effective_dosage: 2% energy replacement for polyunsaturated fats, 5% energy replacement for carbohydrates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of varying dietary fat levels on gene expression related to energy metabolism, oxidative phosphorylation, and lipid synthesis in laying hens.
results_summary: Higher dietary fat increased AME intake and upregulated jejunal PPARγ expression, but did not affect other genes related to mitochondrial energy metabolism or lipogenesis. No differences were observed in body weight, fat pad weight, or mitochondrial count across dietary fat levels.
population_specificity: Laying hens aged 22 to 42 weeks.
effective_dosage: Low fat (25 g/kg DM), medium fat (61 g/kg DM), high fat (73 g/kg DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of high-fat and ketogenic diets on cognitive function in postweaning mice and rats and determine potential underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The abstract describes a systematic review protocol but does not report specific findings; it outlines the methodology for analyzing cognitive outcomes and potential mechanisms of high-fat diet effects.
population_specificity: Postweaning mice and rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how excessive dietary fat intake, particularly during pregnancy, affects hypothalamic development and ingestive behavior in offspring, leading to obesity and metabolic disorders.
results_summary: The study found that prenatal exposure to a high-fat diet increases neurogenesis of orexigenic neuropeptide systems in offspring, leading to behavioral changes that promote excessive consumption and obesity. These effects can persist across multiple generations and involve molecular mechanisms such as inflammation, gut microbiota changes, and epigenetic modifications.
population_specificity: Animal models (offspring exposed to high-fat diet during pregnancy)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the sex-specific metabolic responses to different dietary fat compositions (low-fat, Western, and high-fat diets) in C57BL/6 J mice.
results_summary: Male and female mice exhibited different metabolic responses to high-fat diets, with males showing earlier weight gain, reduced locomotor activity, impaired glucose tolerance, and increased pancreatic β cell area, while females displayed increased energy expenditure and less severe metabolic disruptions.
population_specificity: Male and female C57BL/6 J mice starting at 4 weeks of age.
effective_dosage: Low-fat diet (10% calories from fat), Western Diet (45% calories from fat), high-fat diet (60% calories from fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different ratios of unsaturated to saturated fatty acids (UFA to SFA) in pig diets affect growth performance, blood lipids, tissue composition, and meat quality.
results_summary: Increasing the UFA to SFA ratio improved blood lipid profiles and tissue fatty acid composition but negatively impacted growth performance and meat quality (e.g., increased drip loss, decreased meat color scores).
population_specificity: Finishing pigs (crossbred [Duroc×Landrace]×Yorkshire) with an initial body weight of 60.3±2.4 kg.
effective_dosage: Three dietary UFA to SFA ratios (1:1, 2:1, 3:1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between dietary fat intake and erythrocyte membrane fatty acid levels with the risk of uterine fibroids in premenopausal women.
results_summary: No associations were found between dietary fat intake and fibroid risk, but erythrocyte n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids showed an inverse association with fibroids, while trans fatty acids were associated with increased odds of fibroids.
population_specificity: Premenopausal US women aged 25-42 years from the Nurses' Health Study II.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of different types of dietary fats on cancer risk and progression, focusing on their composition rather than total fat content.
results_summary: The study found that the type of dietary fat (saturated, monounsaturated, polyunsaturated, and trans fats) has varying effects on cancer risk, with plant-based monounsaturated fats (e.g., olive oil) showing protective effects, while ω-6 PUFAs may promote tumor growth. Human data on ω-3 PUFAs and trans fats were inconclusive.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human population inferred).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether "fat taste" is a distinct taste modality and how dietary fat intervention modulates fat taste perception, potentially influencing obesity.
results_summary: The study found that dietary fat content modulates fat taste sensitivity, with high-fat diets downregulating and low-fat diets upregulating sensitivity. Reduced oro-sensory detection of long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) may lead to increased fat intake and obesity.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of taste physiology)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how varying intake ratios of n-3/n6 PUFAs affect gut microbiota composition in a rat model of autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: The study found that an n-3/n6 (1:5) diet increased fecal microbial abundance and reduced elevated Firmicutes in VPA-exposed rats, suggesting potential benefits for gut microbiota in ASD-like conditions. The gut microbiota changes mirrored those reported in ASD patients.
population_specificity: Pregnant female Wistar rats and their male offspring, with a subset exposed to valproate acid (VPA) to model ASD.
study_duration: Duration of dietary intervention not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether autonomous motivation and self-efficacy mediated the association between a lifestyle behavior intervention and reduced dietary fat intake in low-income overweight or obese women with young children.
results_summary: The intervention increased autonomous motivation, which subsequently enhanced self-efficacy, and higher self-efficacy was associated with decreased dietary fat intake. The study concluded that promoting peer encouragement and practical skills could enhance motivation and self-efficacy to reduce dietary fat intake.
population_specificity: Low-income overweight or obese women with young children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and test genome-wide genetic scores to predict how dietary fat affects six cardiometabolic risk factors (CRFs) in women.
results_summary: Only one genetic score (for LDL cholesterol) predicted changes in the associated CRF, explaining 3.7% of variance in 1-year LDL cholesterol changes in the intervention arm. The study found no significant associations for other CRFs or in the control arm.
population_specificity: Women from the Women's Health Initiative cohort (n ∼ 9000 for analysis, n ∼ 5000 for testing).
study_duration: 1-year intervention, with long-term follow-up for chronic disease outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increased dietary fat (high oleic sunflower oil) could counteract the inhibitory effects of trans-10, cis-12 CLA on milk fat concentration in lactating mice.
results_summary: High-fat diets increased milk fat percentage by over 16%, while CLA reduced it by over 12%, but dietary fat did not overcome CLA's inhibition. Both CLA and high-fat diets reduced short- and medium-chain fatty acids from de novo synthesis, with no interaction between them.
population_specificity: Lactating wild-type C57Bl/6J mice (n = 31).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize human intervention studies investigating the effect of dietary fat quantity and quality on subcutaneous white adipose tissue (WAT) inflammation, focusing on TLR4/NF-κB and NLRP3 inflammasome signaling pathways.
results_summary: The study found that firm conclusions about the effect of dietary fat quantity and quality on WAT inflammatory responses are difficult to draw due to heterogeneous study designs, diet compositions, and participant cohorts. Previous studies mainly focused on WAT gene expression, but future work should include measures of WAT protein content and phosphorylation for better physiological relevance.
population_specificity: Human participants (specific cohort details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different dietary fat sources (soybean oil, coconut oil, fish oil) on colostrum quality and inflammatory response in sows challenged with LPS.
results_summary: Maternal LPS challenge reduced colostrum yield and dry matter content, increased inflammatory markers, and decreased piglet growth performance. Fish oil supplementation attenuated the LPS-induced inflammatory response in mammary glands.
population_specificity: Sixty Landrace × Yorkshire sows from Day 90 of gestation until parturition.
effective_dosage: 3% supplementation of soybean oil, coconut oil, or fish oil.
study_duration: From Day 90 of gestation until parturition (approximately 21-28 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the modifying effects of dietary fatty acids and obesity on breast cancer biomarkers related to DNA methylation.
results_summary: The study highlights evidence linking dietary fat consumption and obesity to breast cancer incidence and explores how these factors influence DNA methylation biomarkers, which may impact risk, prognosis, and treatment response.
population_specificity: Women (focus on breast cancer risk and biomarkers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how variations in dietary fat and sugar content in maternal meals affect macronutrient and metabolic hormone concentrations in breast milk.
results_summary: The study will provide novel evidence on how different fat and sugar levels in maternal diets alter breast milk composition, but specific results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: 25 lactating women.
effective_dosage: Breakfast meals with 9 g fat (standard), 28 g fat (high-fat), or 5 g fat (high-sugar).
study_duration: Three days of intervention with measurements over 12 hours post-meal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the distribution of CB1R in hypothalamic nuclei and its potential changes due to high-fat diet (HFD) and nicotine exposure.
results_summary: CB1R was widely distributed in hypothalamic nuclei, with higher expression in the arcuate and lateral nuclei. Nicotine suppressed food intake and body weight in HFD-fed mice, and combined HFD and nicotine treatment increased CB1R levels in specific hypothalamic nuclei.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice
study_duration: Four weeks of HFD followed by nicotine challenge

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal dietary fat interventions for treating metabolic syndrome and its components.
results_summary: Replacing carbohydrates with fats, especially polyunsaturated fats, improved triglyceride levels, HDL cholesterol, and blood pressure but did not affect fasting glucose or insulin sensitivity. Monounsaturated fats were preferable for lowering fasting insulin and glucose, while N3 fats and dairy fat also showed benefits in reducing metabolic syndrome incidence.
population_specificity: Volunteers with metabolic syndrome and normal volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between dietary fat amount/type and glycemia, as well as optimal insulin adjustments for dietary fat in individuals with type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: Increasing dietary fat reduced early postprandial glucose but increased late postprandial glucose, with no significant difference based on fat type. Optimal insulin adjustments required dual-wave bolus with increased insulin for higher fat meals.
population_specificity: Adults with type 1 diabetes using insulin pump therapy.
effective_dosage: Meals contained 45 g carbohydrate with 0 g, 20 g, 40 g, or 60 g fat (saturated, monounsaturated, or polyunsaturated).
study_duration: Participants attended the clinic on 9-12 occasions (duration not specified).
interactions: Insulin adjustments were required for dietary fat, but no other interactions mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of dietary fat restriction, alongside octreotide, in managing chylous effusions (chylothoraces and chylopericardium) in a patient with Hodgkin's Lymphoma.
results_summary: The study found that dietary fat restriction, combined with octreotide, helped control the effusions until chemotherapy took effect, suggesting a supportive role in managing chylous complications.
population_specificity: A single patient with Hodgkin's Lymphoma presenting with bilateral chylothoraces and chylopericardium.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of substituting unsaturated fat (PUFA) for saturated fat (SFA) on LDL cholesterol and apoB concentrations in normal-weight versus obese individuals with elevated LDL cholesterol.
results_summary: The PUFA diet significantly lowered LDL cholesterol and apoB compared to the SFA diet, with greater improvements observed in normal-weight participants than in obese individuals. BMI modified the lipid response, suggesting dietary recommendations may need adjustment based on BMI.
population_specificity: 83 men and women (aged 21-70 y) with elevated LDL cholesterol, stratified into normal-weight (BMI ≤ 25 kg/m²) and obese (BMI: 30-45) groups.
effective_dosage: Diets differed by ~9 energy percent (E%) in SFA and ~4 E% in PUFA between groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of the MTNR1B gene polymorphism (rs10830963) on cardiovascular risk factors and weight loss in obese subjects following two different hypocaloric diets (high monounsaturated fat vs. high polyunsaturated fat).
results_summary: Both diets improved anthropometric parameters, with greater improvements in non-G allele carriers. The high monounsaturated fat diet showed significant improvements in total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, insulin, and HOMA-IR in non-G allele carriers, while the high polyunsaturated fat diet improved insulin levels and HOMA-IR in the same group.
population_specificity: 361 obese subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of dietary fat modification (specifically high-fat vs. low-fat diets with different fat compositions) on insulin secretion in subjects with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found no overall effect of dietary fat modification on insulin secretion in the total cohort. However, in normoglycemic subjects with preserved first-phase insulin secretion, a high-monounsaturated fat diet (HMUFA) improved insulin response compared to a high-saturated fat diet (HSFA).
population_specificity: Subjects with metabolic syndrome (n=486).
effective_dosage: 1.2 g/day of n-3 PUFA supplementation (for the LFHCC n-3 group).

study_goal: To investigate how diets differing in fat content alter gut microbiota, faecal metabolomic profiles, and their relationship with cardiometabolic risk factors in healthy adults transitioning from a traditional low-fat diet to a higher-fat diet.
results_summary: The lower-fat diet increased gut microbiota diversity and beneficial bacteria, while the higher-fat diet increased proinflammatory bacteria and decreased beneficial bacteria. Higher-fat consumption was associated with unfavourable changes in gut microbiota, metabolomic profiles, and elevated plasma proinflammatory factors.
population_specificity: 217 healthy young adults (aged 18-35 years; BMI <28 kg/m²; 52% women).
effective_dosage: Three isocaloric diets: lower-fat (20% energy from fat), moderate-fat (30% energy from fat), higher-fat (40% energy from fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of dietary fat supplementation on methane emissions and milk yield in cows fed diets containing either corn or wheat grains.
results_summary: Cows fed wheat had greater methane yield (MY) than those fed corn, but increasing dietary fat from 2% to 6% dry matter reduced MY regardless of grain type. The study concluded that grain type does not affect the methane-mitigating effects of dietary fat supplements.
population_specificity: 32 Holstein-Friesian dairy cows
effective_dosage: 0.8 kg of canola oil added to 8 kg of dry matter/d of corn or wheat

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing dietary fat content (20% vs. 10% crude fat) improves growth performance and thermal resilience in juvenile barramundi.
results_summary: A high-fat diet increased fish weight but did not improve thermal sensitivity of swimming performance or metabolism. It reduced thermal tolerance by 0.48°C, compromising upper thermal limits.
population_specificity: Juvenile barramundi (Lates calcarifer)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-saturated-fat diet promotes pancreatic cancer growth via the CCK-receptor pathway, independent of obesity.
results_summary: The study found that a high-saturated-fat diet significantly increased pancreatic cancer growth and metastasis, mediated by the CCK-receptor pathway, and that CCK-receptor antagonist therapy reduced tumor fibrosis, altered metalloprotease expression, and increased tumor suppressor genes.
population_specificity: Syngeneic murine models (mice) before obesity onset and genetically engineered CCK peptide knockout mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how dietary fat and sucrose content in control diets influence osteoarthritis pathology and cartilage metabolism in mice.
results_summary: The study found that higher dietary fat increased fatty acid metabolic enzymes in cartilage, while sucrose content in low-fat diets significantly affected serum metabolites and joint pathology. The findings suggest that altered cartilage metabolism may link diet and obesity to osteoarthritis risk.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice aged 6 to 26 weeks.
effective_dosage: Not specified (diets varied in fat and sucrose content).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate metabolic adaptations to fat-rich diets, comparing saturated and polyunsaturated fats, and their effects on insulin sensitivity, fat oxidation, and other metabolic markers.
results_summary: Both saturated and polyunsaturated fat-rich diets increased fat oxidation potential in muscle, improved hepatic insulin clearance, and reduced glucose production, de novo lipogenesis, and plasma triacylglycerol. The diets also induced immune-supportive plasma proteome changes and gut microbiome alterations, with no adverse effects on peripheral insulin sensitivity.
population_specificity: Healthy, slightly overweight men.
effective_dosage: Not specified (fat-rich diets, but exact quantities not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of herbacetin on high-fat diet-induced hyperglycemia and hyperlipidemia in mice.
results_summary: Herbacetin significantly reduced body weight, blood glucose, insulin resistance, and lipid levels in mice fed a high-fat diet. It also improved hepatic lipid metabolism by regulating key enzymes and reducing lipid droplets in liver tissue.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice with obesity-associated insulin resistance induced by a high-fat diet.
effective_dosage: Different doses (specific amounts not provided in the abstract).
study_duration: 5 weeks of herbacetin administration alongside continued high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different dietary fat sources, including modified distillers grains plus solubles (MDGS), on beef display life, color stability, and lipid oxidation.
results_summary: Feeding MDGS increased linoleic acid and polyunsaturated fatty acids but reduced color and lipid stability in beef compared to corn diets. De-oiled MDGS plus corn oil further decreased redness and increased discoloration and lipid oxidation.
population_specificity: Steers (n = 256)
effective_dosage: 40% full-fat MDGS, 40% de-oiled MDGS, or 38% de-oiled MDGS plus 2% corn oil

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether β-adrenergic antagonists (like propranolol) reduce dietary fat absorption by regulating pancreatic lipase (PNLIP) expression in pancreatic acinar cells during high-fat diet feeding.
results_summary: Propranolol mitigated body weight gain and increased fecal fat excretion in high-fat diet-fed mice by downregulating PNLIP expression, which was otherwise upregulated by sympathetic activation via a cAMP/PKA/CREB pathway.
population_specificity: Male six-week-old C57BL/6 mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adaptations in fat oxidation and carbohydrate metabolism from high-fat, low-carbohydrate diets are driven by high fat intake or low carbohydrate availability.
results_summary: The study found that high dietary fat intake increased whole-body fat oxidation and reduced skeletal muscle mitochondrial respiration, which returned to baseline after reintroducing carbohydrates. These effects were attributed to high fat intake rather than low carbohydrate availability.
population_specificity: 8 male cyclists
effective_dosage: High-fat diet (>65% energy intake), high-protein diet (>65% energy intake), with carbohydrate intake clamped at <20% energy intake

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of short-term sex hormone suppression with or without testosterone add-back on postprandial metabolism and the fate of dietary fat in healthy males.
results_summary: The study found that short-term hormone suppression did not affect energy expenditure or postprandial metabolism but led to greater relative storage of dietary fat in the femoral depot. Dietary fat oxidation trended lower, and uptake of labeled lipid into femoral adipose tissue was greater in the low hormone condition.
population_specificity: Eleven healthy males (age: 29 ± 4.5 years; BMI: 26.3 ± 2.1 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Not specified (test meal contained 50 μCi of [1-14 C] oleic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ALA-DAG consumption increases dietary fat oxidation and reduces visceral fat compared to ALA-TAG in humans.
results_summary: ALA-DAG significantly increased dietary fat oxidation and decreased visceral fat area compared to ALA-TAG, suggesting potential benefits for obesity prevention.
population_specificity: 17 normal and moderately obese men and women (BMI: 25.7±2.0 kg/m²).
study_duration: 4-week intervention periods with a 4-week washout between diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of dietary fat intake on inflammatory markers in overweight and obese individuals based on human randomized controlled trials from 2010 to 2016.
results_summary: Most dietary fat interventions showed minor or no effects on inflammatory markers, with the most consistent effects observed in whole-diet interventions. Weight reduction and different fatty acids did not clearly demonstrate beneficial effects on inflammation.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the nutrigenetic role of the ACE rs4343 variant in glucose metabolism under varying dietary fat conditions.
results_summary: The study found that GG-carriers of the rs4343 variant experienced significant declines in glucose tolerance after a high-fat diet, with higher 2-hour glucose and insulin concentrations compared to AA/AG-carriers. The gene-diet interaction was confirmed in a cross-sectional study, linking GG-genotypes to higher type 2 diabetes risk with high dietary fat intake.
population_specificity: 46 healthy, non-obese twin pairs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how the LIPC rs1800588 genotype modifies the effects of dietary fat (high-fat Western vs. low-fat Hispanic diets) on lipids and glucose in Caribbean Hispanic individuals.
results_summary: Major allele carriers (CC/CT) of LIPC rs1800588 had higher HDL-C levels on a high-fat Western diet compared to a low-fat Hispanic diet, while TT carriers showed no difference. In a secondary analysis, saturated fat was unfavorably associated with HDL-C and triglycerides in TT carriers.
population_specificity: Caribbean Hispanic descent (n = 42 in the intervention study; subset n = 384 in the observational analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different dietary fats affect gene transcription related to lipid metabolism in adipose tissue and the liver in growing pigs.
results_summary: Dietary fats, regardless of source, altered mRNA abundance of genes involved in lipid metabolism in both adipose tissue and the liver. Omega-3 fatty acids suppressed lipolysis-related genes, while saturated fatty acids (SFA) inhibited lipogenesis more than omega-6 fatty acids. Medium-chain fatty acids influenced hepatic lipid metabolism differently than long-chain fatty acids.
population_specificity: Growing pigs (Genetiporc 6.0 × Genetiporc F25 barrows, initial BW 44.1 ± 1.2 kg).
effective_dosage: 5% of diet (cornstarch control or one of five fat sources: animal-vegetable blend, coconut oil, corn oil, fish oil, or tallow).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how dietary fat influences gut microbiota composition, systemic inflammation, and obesity-related metabolic effects.
results_summary: High-fat diets, particularly those rich in saturated fats, were linked to negative changes in gut microbiota, increased inflammation, and obesity-related metabolic dysregulation, while monounsaturated and omega-3 polyunsaturated fats showed beneficial effects. Probiotic therapy was found ineffective for long-term correction of fat-induced dysbiosis.
population_specificity: Human health (general population, not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of reduced dietary fat on serum estradiol, adiponectin, and IGF-1 levels in postmenopausal Mexican women with breast cancer.
results_summary: Reduced dietary fat led to significant decreases in BMI, waist circumference, serum estradiol, and adiponectin, but no significant changes in IGF-1 or testosterone. BMI was correlated with adiponectin and estradiol levels.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal Mexican women with breast cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alpha linolenic acid-enriched diacylglycerol (ALA-DAG) enhances dietary fat oxidation compared to control triacylglycerol (TAG).
results_summary: ALA-DAG consumption significantly increased dietary fat utilization as energy compared to TAG. The study demonstrated a measurable improvement in fat oxidation with ALA-DAG supplementation.
population_specificity: 16 subjects (specific demographics not provided).
study_duration: 14 days per intervention, with a 21-day washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of varying dietary fat content on oxidative stress-induced glucose intolerance and organ-specific metabolic responses.
results_summary: A 60% fat diet induced glucose intolerance, elevated ALT, and reduced GSH levels, with tissue-specific oxidative stress modulation. Withdrawal to a standard diet reversed oxidative damage, particularly in the liver, and identified differential gene expression linked to oxidative stress and mitochondrial biogenesis.
population_specificity: Animal model (rats)
study_duration: 12 weeks (with a 10-week withdrawal period for one group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms linking dietary fat (specifically a high-fat ketogenic diet) to tumor growth in BRAF V600E-expressing melanoma.
results_summary: A high-fat ketogenic diet increased serum acetoacetate levels, enhancing tumor growth in BRAF V600E-expressing melanoma cells in mice. Lowering acetoacetate levels or inhibiting its binding to BRAF V600E attenuated tumor growth.
population_specificity: Xenograft mice with BRAF V600E-expressing human melanoma cells.
interactions: Hypolipidemic agents and dehydroacetic acid were noted to interact with acetoacetate effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different dietary fats (linseed oil, rapeseed oil, beef tallow) affect the metabolism and deposition of saturated (SFA) and monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) in growing pigs.
results_summary: The study found that while total accumulation of SFA and MUFA was similar across diets, elongation and desaturation processes varied depending on the type of dietary fat. High MUFA intake inhibited desaturation compared to SFA- and PUFA-rich diets, while high SFA intake reduced elongation rates. Increased net intake of SFA and MUFA was linked to lower de novo production of these fatty acids in pigs.
population_specificity: Growing gilts (female pigs) with an initial body weight of 60 kg.
effective_dosage: 50 g/kg diet (isoenergetic and isonitrogenous experimental diets).
study_duration: Until pigs reached 105 kg (specific duration not stated).

study_goal: To determine how intestinally and liver-derived lipoproteins contribute to postprandial plasma triacylglycerol (TAG) response in APOE3/E3 and E3/E4 individuals after chronic dietary fat manipulation.
results_summary: The study found that dietary fat composition significantly affected the Sf > 400 apoB-48 response and particle TAG content in E4 carriers compared to E3/E3 individuals, suggesting APOE genotype modulates chylomicron particle synthesis. No genotype impact on apoB-100 responses was observed.
population_specificity: APOE3/E3 (n=12) and E3/E4 (n=11) individuals.
effective_dosage: High-saturated fat (HSF) diet with 3.45 g/day docosahexaenoic acid (HSF-DHA).

study_goal: The researchers sought to identify dietary constituents that determine susceptibility to body fat accretion in germfree mice and explore the interaction between gut microbiota and cholesterol metabolism.
results_summary: Germfree mice were resistant to diet-induced obesity when fed a cholesterol-rich lard-based high-fat diet but not a cholesterol-free palm oil-based diet. This resistance was linked to increased energy expenditure, carbohydrate oxidation, and fecal fat excretion, along with shifts in bile acid and steroid metabolites.
population_specificity: Germfree and specific pathogen-free male C57BL/6N mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified (high-fat diets based on lard or palm oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how high-fat diets induce changes in skeletal muscle gene expression, particularly through pre-mRNA alternative splicing, and whether these changes depend on dietary fat quantity and type.
results_summary: High-fat diets (60% fat) caused alternative splicing of hundreds of pre-mRNAs in rat skeletal muscle, with Tnnt3 splicing changes observed even at lower fat levels (30%). These effects were dependent on fat type, occurring with saturated fats (lard) but not mono- or polyunsaturated fats, and were independent of obesity.
population_specificity: Male obesity-prone Sprague-Dawley rats
effective_dosage: 10%, 30%, 45%, or 60% fat diets (lard or unsaturated fats)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationships between intervention effects on temptations to eat high-fat foods and the stage of readiness to avoid them.
results_summary: The study found that baseline levels of temptations, but not the rate of change in temptations, were significantly related to changes in readiness to avoid high-fat foods. The data pooled from three randomized controlled trials demonstrated separate simultaneous growth processes in these relationships.
population_specificity: 6,516 participants from three randomized controlled trials (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the utility of the Geiselman Food Preference Questionnaire in measuring fat preference in patients with anorexia nervosa before and after weight restoration, compared to healthy participants.
results_summary: Patients with anorexia nervosa had significantly lower fat preference scores than healthy participants both before and after weight restoration, though scores increased slightly with weight gain. The findings suggest that even after weight restoration, patients with anorexia nervosa continue to prefer lower-fat foods compared to healthy individuals.
population_specificity: 88 patients with anorexia nervosa and 115 healthy participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of dietary heme combined with high or low dietary fat levels on intestinal carcinogenesis in a mouse model.
results_summary: Dietary hemin significantly reduced colonic carcinogenesis, independent of dietary fat levels, while fat tended to stimulate intestinal carcinogenesis. No association was found between colonic carcinogenesis and fecal TBARS, a lipid oxidation biomarker.
population_specificity: A/J Min/+ mouse model for Apc-driven colorectal cancer.
effective_dosage: High fat (40 energy %), low fat (10 energy %), and heme (0.5 μmol/g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether current dietary fat guidelines, which recommend restricting fat intake to reduce coronary heart disease (CHD) mortality, are supported by randomized controlled trial (RCT) evidence.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in all-cause mortality or CHD mortality between intervention (dietary fat restriction) and control groups, despite greater reductions in serum cholesterol levels in the intervention groups. The evidence does not support the current dietary fat guidelines for reducing CHD risk.
population_specificity: 62,421 participants across 10 dietary trials, including primary and secondary prevention studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association of dietary fat intake during pregnancy and childhood with pregnancy, perinatal, and child health outcomes.
results_summary: Omega-3 fatty acids supplementation during pregnancy reduced early preterm birth risk and increased gestation length and birth weight, but effects on other outcomes were inconsistent. Reduced saturated fatty acids intake in children improved blood pressure and lipids, while total or trans fat showed no apparent effects.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different dietary fat compositions (n-3, n-6, saturated) affect postprandial endotoxemia and systemic inflammation in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found that a saturated fat meal increased postprandial serum endotoxin, while an n-3 meal decreased it; n-6 had no significant effect compared to control. No meal type affected systemic inflammation, but n-6 elevated triacylglycerols and saturated fat increased non-esterified fatty acids.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (n=20, mean age 25 ± 3.2 years).
effective_dosage: Meals provided 20% fat (control) or 35% fat from n-3 (500 mg DHA), n-6 (7.4 g grapeseed oil), or saturated fat (16 g coconut oil).
study_duration: Four test meals, each separated by at least one week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how fructose and high-fat diets synergistically impair dietary fat oxidation and contribute to metabolic complications like NAFLD.
results_summary: Fructose consumption reduces dietary fat oxidation by impairing acylcarnitine production, suppressing PPARα activity, and affecting mitochondrial β-oxidation. Carnitine supplementation can mitigate these effects.
population_specificity: Human and animal studies (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of dietary fat and iron interaction on brain regional iron contents and associated behavior patterns in a mouse model.
results_summary: High-fat diet altered stereotypical behaviors (e.g., inactivity, total distance traveled) and brain iron content in a region-specific manner, particularly decreasing iron in the striatum and altering FtH mRNA expression in the thalamus. Dietary iron also influenced brain iron content and FtH protein expression regionally, with interactions between dietary fat and iron affecting both brain iron and behaviors.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J male weanling mice (n=30, divided into six dietary treatment groups).
effective_dosage: Varying fat (control/high) and iron (control/high/low) contents (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effects of Calanus finmarchicus oil (CO), fish oil (FO), and krill oil (KO) supplementation on omega-3 PUFA status in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: The study found that all three marine oils (CO, FO, KO) comparably increased the Omega-3 Index (O3I) after 12 weeks of supplementation, confirming CO as a viable alternative source of bioavailable omega-3 PUFAs. The O3I increases were statistically significant and similar across groups (CO: 1.09%, FO: 1.0%, KO: 1.15%).
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers (mean age 29.7 ± 8.43 years).
effective_dosage: CO: 242 mg EPA+DHA/day (4 capsules), FO: 248 mg EPA+DHA/day (1 capsule), KO: 286 mg EPA+DHA/day (2 capsules).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of omega-3 supplementation on social, verbal, and behavioral activities in children with autism spectrum disorders (ASD).
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 supplementation significantly improved stereotyped behaviors, social communication, and overall GARS-2 scores in children with ASD, but no significant change was observed in social interaction subscale scores.
population_specificity: 54 children diagnosed with autism spectrum disorders (ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary counselling focusing on dietary fat, fibre, and saccharose intake could improve micronutrient intakes among pregnant women at increased risk of gestational diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The dietary counselling increased the intake of niacin equivalent, vitamin D, vitamin E, and magnesium, and maintained folate intake from early pregnancy to 36-37 weeks' gestation. The mean intake of most micronutrients was adequate in both groups, except for folate and vitamin D, which still required supplementation.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in Finland at increased risk of gestational diabetes mellitus (n=399).
study_duration: From early pregnancy to 36-37 weeks' gestation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of dietary fat types in the pathogenesis of obesity and cardiometabolic diseases, as part of Ancel Keys' legacy in obesity research.
results_summary: The abstract highlights Ancel Keys' foundational work on dietary fat's impact on cardiovascular health and obesity, but specific results on dietary fat's effects are not detailed in the provided text. The supplement reviews current concepts, including dietary fat's role in disease pathways.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract (general obesity research context).

study_goal: To evaluate strategies for enhancing absorption of EPA and DHA from dietary supplements, particularly in the absence of dietary fat.
results_summary: The study found that absorption enhancement technologies, such as in-situ emulsification, significantly improved the bioavailability of EPA and DHA, even without a fat-containing meal. Randomized controlled trials demonstrated marked improvements in absorption efficacy.
population_specificity: General population (average American diet)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the efficacy of Encala™, a structured lipid, varied based on the severity of baseline fat malabsorption in children with cystic fibrosis and pancreatic insufficiency.
results_summary: Encala™ significantly improved fat absorption, plasma fatty acid levels, and growth metrics in subjects with severe baseline fat malabsorption, while showing safety and tolerability. High baseline fat absorption subjects also saw some benefits in weight and fatty acids.
population_specificity: Children with cystic fibrosis and pancreatic insufficiency (n=66, aged 10.5±3.0 years, 39% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health impacts of replacing saturated fatty acids (SFA) with polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA), particularly EPA, DHA, and ALA, and to identify gaps in evidence regarding ALA's efficacy.
results_summary: High SFA intake is linked to increased CVD and T2D risk, while PUFA (especially EPA and DHA) shows anti-inflammatory benefits. ALA's optimal dose for health benefits may exceed current guidelines, but more research is needed.
population_specificity: General population in Ireland and other European countries.
effective_dosage: ALA suggested benefit at >2 g/d (0.6-1% TE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether α-cyclodextrin (α-CD) supplementation increases fecal excretion of dietary fat in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in fecal fat content or plasma triglyceride appearance between α-CD and placebo treatments, indicating α-CD did not enhance dietary fat excretion. Tripalmitin-derived fat showed less plasma appearance than triolein-derived fat, suggesting different metabolic handling of these fats.
population_specificity: Eight healthy volunteers (5 premenopausal women, 3 men) aged 23-54 with BMI 18-27.
effective_dosage: 2 g of α-CD per meal for 3 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different types of dietary fats, particularly saturated fatty acids (SFAs), on cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk.
results_summary: The study found that replacing SFAs with unsaturated fats, especially polyunsaturated fatty acids, significantly reduces CVD risk. Industrially produced trans fats were consistently linked to higher CVD risk, while both n-6 and n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids were associated with lower risk, though fish oil supplementation showed inconsistent results.
population_specificity: General population (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether LYM-X-SORB (LXS), an easily absorbable lipid matrix, improves dietary fat absorption in patients with cystic fibrosis and pancreatic insufficiency compared to placebo.
results_summary: LXS significantly increased plasma fatty acids and linoleic acid levels at 3 and 12 months, with a 6% improvement in fat absorption, and was associated with better growth status compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 110 subjects with cystic fibrosis and pancreatic insufficiency (mean age 10.4 ± 3.0 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how diets rich in saturated fatty acids (SFA) or omega-6 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-6PUFA), both supplemented with long-chain omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (LCn-3PUFA), affect plasma lipid levels and lipoprotein profiles in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The n-6PUFA-rich diet reduced LDL particle concentration and LDL cholesterol levels, while the SFA-rich diet did not significantly affect LDL profiles but increased LCn-3PUFA in plasma and tissue lipids, potentially lowering other cardiovascular risk factors like inflammation and clotting tendency.
population_specificity: 26 healthy subjects with an adequate omega-3 index.
study_duration: Four-week pre-supplementation period followed by randomization to dietary interventions (duration of dietary intervention not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a very low-fat diet (11.3% of total energy) or soy food supplementation (50 mg isoflavones or 15 g soy protein) affects serum levels of adipocytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, adiponectin, resistin) in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant changes in adipocytokine levels with either the very low-fat diet or soy supplementation, except for a borderline significant change in TNF-α levels between the very low-fat and control diet groups.
population_specificity: 57 healthy postmenopausal women
effective_dosage: Very low-fat diet (11.3% of total energy), soy supplementation (50 mg isoflavones or 15 g soy protein as tofu)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the need for a nutritional supplement rich in essential nutrients, including ω-3 fatty acids, to provide comprehensive cardioprotection.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that ω-3 fatty acids have multifactorial cardioprotective effects, and a cardioceutical containing these nutrients in the right proportion may offer all-round heart protection.
population_specificity: The Indian subcontinent, particularly with increasing affluence and urbanization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of dietary fat restriction and vitamin supplementation in managing genetic diseases (ABL and FHBL) characterized by low-density lipoprotein deficiency.
results_summary: Dietary fat restriction was recommended to prevent steatorrhea in ABL and homozygous FHBL, while high-dose vitamin E and A supplementation was advised to slow neuromuscular and retinal degeneration. Heterozygous FHBL individuals did not require vitamin E supplementation despite low plasma levels.
population_specificity: Individuals with abetalipoproteinemia (ABL) and familial hypobetalipoproteinemia (FHBL), including heterozygous and homozygous cases.
effective_dosage: High-dose vitamin E and A supplementation (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D-3 absorption is enhanced when taken with a fat-containing meal compared to a fat-free meal, and whether the type of fat (MUFA:PUFA ratio) affects absorption.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D-3 absorption was 32% greater when taken with a fat-containing meal compared to a fat-free meal, but the MUFA:PUFA ratio of the fat did not significantly influence absorption.
population_specificity: 50 healthy older men and women

study_goal: To investigate the association between increased dietary intake of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and the risk of developing Crohn's disease (CD).
results_summary: Higher quintiles of DHA intake were inversely associated with the development of CD, with the highest quintile showing the greatest effect size (OR = 0.07). No associations were found with other dietary fatty acids.
population_specificity: 229,702 participants recruited from nine European centers between 1991 and 1998.
effective_dosage: Quintiles of DHA intake (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the quality of dietary fat (Mediterranean vs. saturated fatty acid-rich) and Coenzyme Q10 supplementation affect postprandial gene expression and protein levels related to p53-dependent DNA repair in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The Mediterranean diet, especially when supplemented with Coenzyme Q10, downregulated DNA damage-related gene expression and protein levels compared to a saturated fatty acid-rich diet, suggesting a beneficial effect on DNA repair mechanisms.
population_specificity: Elderly participants (20 individuals).
effective_dosage: Not specified (isocaloric diets with varying fat compositions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early enteral supplementation with Microlipid and fish oil increases fat absorption and reduces the need for intravenous fat emulsion in premature infants with an enterostomy.
results_summary: The treatment group showed higher enteral fat absorption, less fecal liquid, and drier feces compared to the control group, along with reduced intravenous fat emulsion requirements. These effects were more pronounced in infants with a high ostomy.
population_specificity: Premature infants (<2 months old) with an enterostomy after surgical treatment for necrotizing enterocolitis or spontaneous intestinal perforation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify proteome-diet interactions during the postprandial state after acute intake of meals with different fat qualities (HSFA, HMUFA, HPUFA) in metabolic syndrome patients.
results_summary: HSFA intake increased proteins linked to oxidative stress and DNA damage, HMUFA upregulated stress-response proteins, and HPUFA with n-3 PUFA improved insulin signaling and had anti-inflammatory effects compared to other fats.
population_specificity: 39 metabolic syndrome patients
effective_dosage: Not specified (acute intake of single meals)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the presence and fat content of a meal influence vitamin D absorption or the 25(OH)D response to supplemental vitamin D3.
results_summary: The study found that absorption of a 50,000 IU vitamin D3 dose was significantly greater when taken with a low-fat meal compared to a high-fat meal or no meal, but this did not result in higher plasma 25(OH)D levels over time.
population_specificity: Sixty-two healthy older men and women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the bioavailability of zeaxanthin from spirulina when consumed with dietary fat in healthy human volunteers.
results_summary: The study found that spirulina increased serum zeaxanthin levels, with detectable labelled zeaxanthin in circulation for up to 45 days. American subjects showed a higher area under the serum response curve compared to Chinese subjects.
population_specificity: Fourteen healthy male volunteers (four Americans and ten Chinese).
effective_dosage: Single servings of 4.0-5.0 g spirulina containing 2.6-3.7 mg zeaxanthin, consumed with 12 g dietary fat.
study_duration: Blood samples were collected over 45 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the quality of dietary fat affects postprandial oxidative stress and if CoQ supplementation improves antioxidant response in an elderly population.
results_summary: Mediterranean diets (with and without CoQ) reduced oxidative stress markers and improved antioxidant protein levels compared to a saturated fatty acid-rich diet. CoQ supplementation further enhanced these effects by lowering postprandial oxidative stress and modifying antioxidant gene expression.
population_specificity: Elderly participants (20 individuals)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the quality of dietary fat and CoQ supplementation affects inflammatory response and endoplasmic reticulum stress-related gene expression in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The Mediterranean diet (Med) and Med + CoQ diets reduced fasting and postprandial expression of inflammatory and stress-related genes compared to the saturated fatty acid-rich diet (SFA). Med + CoQ also uniquely modulated postprandial gene expression of p65 and IKK-b.
population_specificity: Elderly persons (20 participants)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the interaction between dietary fatty acids and ApoE genotype on the risk for Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: The study found that carriers of the ApoE ε4 allele may respond differently to dietary fat and cholesterol changes, with inconsistent protective effects of long-chain n-3 PUFA on cognitive decline. Non-carriers showed increased concentrations of long-chain n-3 PUFA in response to supplementation, while ε4 carriers did not.
population_specificity: Individuals with varying ApoE genotypes, particularly focusing on ε4 carriers and non-carriers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the quality of dietary fat affects postprandial oxidative DNA damage and if CoQ10 supplementation enhances antioxidant capacity by influencing p53 activation in elderly subjects.
